G borrows the relative clause from the verse's part A; syntactic: the new clause functions in attributive relation to the second word ××¨×¥; the new clause is embedded within another clause, i.e. bracketed, though by nature of its being a relative clause. The specification is now repeated in the apodosis, with the result being that the land is specified as coming from the Lord both before and after entry. Does the refocus here have a more exhortational role rather than simply reflective? Lev 26 implies that the land can be taken away and given to others (look for additional evidence). See Lev 26:34, where the land also rests (only other place, cf. SHEBANQ query), but because the inhabitants have been removed. Here the land makes up for the rest that it had lost while the inhabitants lived on it.

Excursus: The Hebraizing tendency of the construction at hand is illustrated by a comparison with the MT (Jupyter). In 58% of cases (87 of 150) where this construction is found in the Pentateuch, it reflects a Hebrew original. The construction is also found to be more common in Semiticizing NT books (Matthew vs. Luke; also John, Revelation, cf. saved NT_attributive.txt as counted in Accordance).

G reads the independent pronoun ×”×•× as in construct with ×ª×‘×•××ª â€œproduce,â€ thus â€œproduce of heâ€ or â€œhis produce.â€ This reading accomplishes two goals: 1) it avoids altering the consonantal layout of the source, 2) the reading brings this part of vs. 16 into cohesion with the previous clauses in vs. 16, which each speak of ××§× ×ª×• â€œhis purchase.â€ With this reading, the text can maintain the flow of logic: â€œhis produce,â€ meaning the produce from his, that is the neighborâ€™s, field.

While the pronoun ×”×•× is never found in a construct relation in the Hebrew Bible, Sam, or Qumran (based on Accordance search), the more general noun + personal pronoun is found twice in the HB (https://shebanq.ancient-data.org/hebrew/query?version=2017&id=2600), once with ×”×™×. Gâ€™s text thus represents a feasible reading.

Thus: â€œall my statutesâ€ and â€œall my judgments.â€ Gâ€™s reading derives from Lev 19:37 and 20:22, where the same formula occurs but with the verb ×©××¨. That Gâ€™s text is sourced from those verses is made clear by the the fact that both texts have ×—×§×ª×™ and ××©×¤×˜×™ as the object of the same verb within the same clause. Gâ€™s text does the same, while in the MT both substantives belong to different object phrases and verbs. With the addition of ÎºÎ±á½· before the second verb, Ï†Ï…Î»á½±Î¾Î±ÏƒÎ¸Îµ, G restructures the clause to accede with Lev 19:37 and 20:22.

Of the two parallel texts, Lev 19:37 shares additional lexemes: the instructions about the fair treatment of neighbors, using the same term, ×¢××™×ª, as Lev 25:14, 15, 17 in 19:11, 15, 17; the instructions not to oppress the sojourner, using the same verb ×™× ×” in 19:33 as in 25:14, 17; the exhortation to fear YHWH, ×•×™×¨××ª ×××œ×”×™×š ×× ×™ ×™×”×•×” in 19:32 and 25:17 (which also influenced the omission of ×›×™ in vs.17.

column12:
G reads a demonstrative pronoun Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„á¿³. There are three general possibilities: 1. G could have inserted the demonstrative simply as a translational element; 2. G could have inserted the demonstrative under the influence of Lev 25:13 where the phrase ×‘×©× ×ª ×”×™×•×‘×œ ×”×–××ª â€œin this year of jubileeâ€ appears; 3. G might have borrowed the demonstrative from its frequent appearance in the Israelitesâ€™ complaints in the Exodus narrative. 

1 is possible, but it is a phenomenon that has not yet been observed in this text (as opposed to, for instance, the frequent addition of definite articles). 2 is likewise possible, but the demonstrative is conspicuously absent from Gâ€™s reading of Lev 25:13 (see the note on that variant). Would G have omitted the demonstrative in one place only to be influenced by it further down? It is, of course, possible. 3 is attractive because A) It is significant that G places the demonstrative in the mouth of the Israelites, i.e. it is a strategic location in the text; and B) the near-demonstrative is found in all but one of the Israelitesâ€™ complaints in the narratives, sometimes in a prominent position. For instance, in Ex 32, ×–×” ××©×” â€œthis Mosesâ€ is fronted at the beginning of the clause and is repeated when Aaron relates the peopleâ€™s words. In the same story, the people declare: ××œ×” ××œ×”×™×š â€œthis is your godsâ€ (see also Ex 16:3 â€œthis wildernessâ€ //Num 14:2, and Num 20:5 â€œthis wicked placeâ€). The additional intertextual elements, such as the presence of ××” in Ex 15:24 and the similar parallel grammar ××” × ×©×ª×” with Lev 25:20 ××” × ××›×œ. The other complaints likewise feature the question particle ××” or ××™ in Ex 14:1, 16:3, 17:3 (but ×œ××”). In light of these similarities, the Israeliteâ€™s words here in vs. 20, â€œWhat will we eat in this seventh year?â€ very much resemble their complaints elsewhere, a feature that is already present in the MT. Gâ€™s addition of the demonstrative only strengthens that connection.
G reads the plural ×ª×‘××•×ª â€œproduces.â€ The reading is seemingly motivated by the fact that the produce is equivalent of â€œthree years.â€ The plural form is borrowed from vss. 15 and 16.

G reads the 3fs suffix as it has appeared elsewhere in this passage. Here the suffix finds an innerclausal warrant in the form of the 3fs verb ×¢×©×ª, a referent to either ×©× ×ª â€œyearâ€ or ×‘×¨×›×ª â€œblessing.â€

G reads ×™×©×Ÿ × ×•×©×Ÿ â€œold that is oldâ€ which is derived from Lev 26:10. There are numerous links between this passage and Lev 26, including nearly identical language of blessing promised upon the land: that the land would â€œgiveâ€ its yield 26:4//25:19, that the Israelites would eat â€œto satisfactionâ€ ×œ×©×‘×¢ (26:5/25:19, that they would live in â€œsafetyâ€ ×œ×‘×˜×— in their land (26:5//25:19), as well as other parallels outlined by Bergsma (Jubilee, 82-83). By using the term from Lev 26:10, G is showing an awareness of the subsequent material. It is also creating a link between the prosperity described in that passage and this one. They are viewed as the same.

Weversâ€™ flat description of this as â€œlevelingâ€ (Notes, 414) falls short of the reflective interpretation found in this variant.

column12: G reads the preposition as ×› â€œaccording to.â€ It could be the result of a common confusion between the similar letters ×›//×‘. But it should not be overlooked that the reading with kaph fundamentally alters the interpretation from â€œin all the land of your possession, a redemption shall be given for the landâ€ to â€œaccording to all the land of your possession, a redemption shall be given for the land.â€ The first is a simple spatial marker; looks, somewhat reflectively, at the measure of the land in possession.
